project_metadata.paper_title: Validating predictions of burial mounds with field data: the promise and reality of machine learning
project_metadata.journal: Journal of Documentation, Emerald Publishing Limited, DOI 10.1108/JD-05-2022-0096
project_metadata.research_context: Evaluates Machine Learning (CNN) approaches for detecting burial mounds in IKONOS satellite imagery from the Kazanlak Valley, Bulgaria. Compares ML predictions against ground-truthed field data from TRAP pedestrian survey (773 mounds), demonstrating high false positive and false negative rates despite reasonable self-reported model metrics.

evidence.verbatim_quote: tile-based false negative rates were 95–96%, false positive rates were 87–95% of tagged tiles, while true positives were only 5–13%
evidence.methodology_linked: CNN model validation against field data

claims.verbatim_quote: Validation of results against field data showed that self-reported success rates were misleadingly high, and that the model was misidentifying most features
both models failed to identify burial mounds in our study area
even a sophisticated, pre-trained model that is subjected to additional training struggles when confronted by inconsistent and sometimes indistinct features in a varied landscape
Burial mounds are a ubiquitous feature of the Bulgarian landscape
Despite the large number of burial mounds, they are endangered
their visibility in satellite imagery depends on their size, surrounding terrain, and local land cover
ML and other artificial intelligence approaches to remote sensing in archaeology are becoming ever more popular
The literature itself, however, is overwhelmingly positive, reflecting some combination of publication bias and a rhetoric of unconditional success
it is important to document unsuccessful attempts to apply ML techniques to archaeological remote sensing
We had at our disposal high-resolution, multispectral satellite imagery and a dataset of some 773 mounds registered during pedestrian survey
Although we had 600 sq km of imagery, all data for CNN model training and validation came from the 85 sq km TRAP study area within it
After some preliminary experimentation with a range of different pre-trained models, we concluded that ResNet-50 seemed to perform best for our data
We employed a pre-trained CNN model with a low-touch approach to additional training
No accommodation was made for the size of the mound; 100 m diameter mounds filled 34.9% of the cutout, while 10 m diameter mounds covered only 1.4%
Our experience suggests that even a 1:2 (positive:negative) ratio was not sufficient
Counterintuitively, the model provided with training data selected for highly visible mounds (rather than all mounds) performed worse
Although the first model reported a good fit (F1 = 0.87), validation with field data showed the model was confusing our target features with other phenomena
Tiles where the model predicted a mound with >60% probability contained a mound only 12.8% of the time – yielding a high rate of false positives (87.1%)
despite additional curation of the training data, the second run was even less successful than the first; the false positives and false negatives increased and fewer mounds were detected
The high number of both false negatives and false positives demonstrated that our use of a low-touch approach – a pre-trained model plus sufficient but minimally curated training data – did not work
Overfitting in such an extreme manner results in a model that does not generalise well to new data
The model has detected incidental features rather than the mounds themselves, making external validation with field data an essential part of CNN workflows
The greatest surprise was that the model failed to detect the largest mounds in the valley
the question 'what is the CNN actually detecting?' to the fore
Although time-on-task data regarding ML approaches in archaeology is limited, such activities can absorb a lot of resources

the return on additional time spent developing the ML approach diminishes rapidly, since we are already approaching a threshold where training student volunteers to identify mounds would be more efficient
Expert researchers, or even novice volunteers, would have been more reliable
Improving the pre-trained model's performance would require considerable time and resources, on top of the time already invested
Researchers and heritage specialists seeking efficient methods for extracting features from remotely sensed data should weigh the costs and benefits of ML versus manual approaches carefully
Early-majority adopters may find ML difficult to implement effectively in real-life scenarios
Transfer learning based on pre-trained models is sometimes proposed as solution to the problem of limited training data
Use of a pre-trained CNN potentially obviates the need to have large, high-quality, and representative datasets for ML training
This paper offers a cautionary tale about the challenges, limitations, and demands of ML applied to archaeological prospection
training the model with a set of highly variable features with even more varied and complex backgrounds may have misled it regarding the target of detection
Models have been observed to predict class membership based on incidental background features in the periphery of the tiles that happen to accompany the target phenomenon in the centre
care in creating the NOT MOUND tiles is as – if not more – important than the MOUND tiles

It is not clear, however, that an ML approach remains cost effective if these additional steps are taken
Each project must make a decision regarding the trade-offs of different approaches to archaeological prospection using remotely sensed data
As ML approaches become more popular, researchers need more negative examples, discussion of problems, and resourcing information to make informed decisions

implicit_arguments.argument_summary: Self-reported model metrics (F1 scores) are insufficient for evaluating archaeological feature detection without external validation against ground-truthed field data
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: Although the first model reported a good fit (F1 = 0.87), validation with field data showed the model was confusing our target features with other phenomena
underlying_assumptions: Model performance metrics calculated on test data subsets may not reflect real-world performance
Archaeological features require domain expertise to verify identification

implicit_arguments.argument_summary: Publication bias in ML archaeology literature creates unrealistic expectations for potential adopters of the technology
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: The literature itself, however, is overwhelmingly positive, reflecting some combination of publication bias and a rhetoric of unconditional success
underlying_assumptions: Negative results are less likely to be published
Researchers may be incentivised to present only successful applications

implicit_arguments.argument_summary: The variability of archaeological features and heterogeneous landscapes makes them fundamentally different from standard computer vision tasks where ML excels
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: even a sophisticated, pre-trained model that is subjected to additional training struggles when confronted by inconsistent and sometimes indistinct features in a varied landscape
underlying_assumptions: Pre-trained models are optimised for standardised image classification tasks
Archaeological features have inherent variability that ML struggles to generalise

implicit_arguments.argument_summary: Transfer learning may not adequately compensate for domain-specific challenges in archaeological remote sensing
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: Use of a pre-trained CNN potentially obviates the need to have large, high-quality, and representative datasets for ML training, and promises to bring CNN approaches within the reach of smaller-scale projects
underlying_assumptions: Transfer learning promises to reduce training data requirements
These promises may not hold for all archaeological applications

implicit_arguments.argument_summary: The cost-benefit analysis for ML approaches should include transparent reporting of time, expertise, and computational resources
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: We also present time, expertise and resourcing requirements, a rarity in ML-for-archaeology publications
underlying_assumptions: Most ML publications do not report resource requirements
Such information is necessary for informed decision-making

research_designs.verbatim_quote: We developed a pre-trained CNN that was further trained using two datasets: (1) image cutouts of areas where mounds were discovered during pedestrian fieldwork, regardless of how visible the mounds were in the satellite imagery, and (2) image cutouts where a burial mound is clearly visible in the imagery to a human observer
research_designs.rationale: Comparing model performance with different training data curation strategies to assess whether filtering for visible features improves detection accuracy

research_designs.verbatim_quote: We compare the predictions from the two models and their reported success rates measured against ground-truthed data
research_designs.rationale: Using independently collected field survey data as ground truth enables assessment of actual model performance versus self-reported metrics, revealing the gap between F1 scores and real-world detection accuracy

research_designs.design_name: Transfer Learning with Low-Touch Training Approach
research_designs.verbatim_quote: We employed a pre-trained CNN model with a low-touch approach to additional training
research_designs.rationale: Transfer learning allows leveraging pre-trained models (ResNet-50) to reduce training data requirements and computational overhead, making ML accessible to modestly resourced projects. Low-touch approach tests whether minimal training data curation can produce acceptable results

research_designs.verbatim_quote: We also present time, expertise and resourcing requirements, a rarity in ML-for-archaeology publications
research_designs.rationale: Documenting resource requirements (135 person-hours, team composition, computational infrastructure) enables informed comparison between ML and manual approaches for heritage management decisions

research_designs.verbatim_quote: This paper offers a cautionary tale about the challenges, limitations, and demands of ML applied to archaeological prospection
research_designs.rationale: Explicitly positioning the paper as a counterbalance to overwhelmingly positive ML literature, documenting failure to contribute to methodological transparency in the field

methods.verbatim_quote: Rather than training our own model from scratch, we used a pre-trained CNN, a technique known as transfer learning
methods.description: Using a pre-trained Convolutional Neural Network (ResNet-50) pre-trained on ImageNet and fine-tuning it with domain-specific training data for burial mound detection in satellite imagery

methods.verbatim_quote: Mound points taken during fieldwork were used as centroids for the generation of 150 × 150 m square polygons (150 × 150 pixels at 1 m resolution), which were clipped from the IKONOS imagery
methods.description: Creating MOUND and NOT MOUND image cutouts from satellite imagery using GPS coordinates from field survey as centroids for positive training data

methods.verbatim_quote: Data augmentation involves making random modifications and changes to the data during training, introducing noise and variability
methods.description: Applying random modifications (vertical/horizontal flip, random rotation) to training images to prevent overfitting and improve model generalisation

methods.verbatim_quote: The performance of the model was assessed using common evaluation criteria: We calculated F1 scores, precision, recall, and accuracy
methods.description: Calculating standard ML performance metrics (F1 score, precision, recall, accuracy) to assess model performance on test data

methods.verbatim_quote: After the initial performance evaluation, we manually validated model performance. To do so, we verified mound predictions using points marking ground-truthed mounds
methods.description: Comparing CNN tile predictions against GPS coordinates of field-verified burial mounds to calculate true/false positive and negative rates

methods.verbatim_quote: This fieldwork covered some 85 sq km, inspected directly via pedestrian survey
methods.description: Systematic ground-based archaeological survey to identify and record burial mounds, including GPS coordinates, dimensions (height, diameter), surface land use, and preservation status

methods.verbatim_quote: We fused the panchromatic and multispectral bands during 2009 fieldwork, to combine the high resolution of the panchromatic with the additional information of the multispectral bands
methods.description: Pan-sharpening (fusing panchromatic 1m and multispectral 4m bands), mosaicing two IKONOS scenes, and coordinate system projection (EPSG:32635)

methods.verbatim_quote: Figure 2 displays the annual publication count in each of the past 10 years (n = 70; research articles and conference papers plus one preprint) in Web of Science
methods.description: Systematic search of Web of Science for publications combining archaeology, remote sensing/satellite imagery, and ML/AI, with manual review to eliminate false positives and content analysis of abstracts

methods.verbatim_quote: During a visual examination of the model predictions, we saw that the model avoided the Koprinka reservoir in the middle of the valley
methods.description: Expert visual examination of CNN prediction maps to identify patterns in model behaviour, including which features were correctly/incorrectly identified

Three public GitHub repositories with R and Python scripts for training data preparation, CNN training, prediction, and validation

pass0_metadata.primary_source: Emerald publisher PDF header + title page
pass0_metadata.notes: Paper published in Journal of Documentation under CC BY 4.0 licence. Received August 2022, revised November 2023, accepted February 2024. Four authors from Aarhus University (Denmark) and Macquarie University (Australia).

pass1_evidence.notes: Liberal extraction of quantitative and qualitative evidence. Strong quantitative evidence from two CNN model runs with field validation. Key metrics: 95-96% false negative rates, 87-95% false positive rates, 5-13% true positives. Time investment: 135 person-hours.

pass2_claims.notes: Liberal extraction of claims including empirical findings, interpretive claims, methodological claims, and recommendations. Claims are well-supported by quantitative evidence. Key themes: ML limitations for heterogeneous landscapes, publication bias in ML literature, cost-benefit considerations for ML vs manual approaches.

pass3_rdmap.notes: Liberal extraction of methods and protocols. Core methods include transfer learning with ResNet-50, training data preparation, data augmentation, model evaluation, and field validation. Protocols cover image cutout generation, data splitting, CNN training, prediction, validation against field data, and mound recording. Two-run comparison protocol documents the iterative approach.

pass4_rdmap_rationalization.notes: Added 5 research designs capturing strategic WHY-level decisions: (1) Comparative Two-Run Experimental Design, (2) Field Data Validation Design, (3) Transfer Learning with Low-Touch Training Approach, (4) Cost-Benefit Evaluation Framework, (5) Cautionary Tale Publication Strategy. Added bidirectional implements_designs links to 7 of 9 methods. Methods M04 (Model Performance Evaluation) and M07 (Satellite Image Processing) serve as supporting infrastructure rather than implementing specific research designs.
